Hey gang. We are travelling to Italy in august. Yes. The most busiest time. Lol
Rome Naples Sorrento Florence Verona and Milan. We have notice a large increase in pickpocketing incidences. Any advice on how to carry around money , credit card , cell phone , etc Your input is much appreciated 🤔🙏

comments.comment_text:
If you search on pickpocket you will find a ton of threads (daily) and most contain options to minimise risks, etc. IMO YOU are a bigger risk than the brand or item you buy to avoid being pickpocketed, so be aware of yourself and others and the basics, like not being distracted, pushed, leaving bags open/
accessible so you're seen as easy, etc. TBH stories may or not be true or representative.
I have been on forums for a number of the many countries I've visited, incl high crime places like India and South Africa, and there are always threads about theft, risks, etc and not too much of it is real individual experience, more things people hear. A lot of it is displaced anxiety of being out of control in a strange place, IMO. In a risky situation, getting on transport, in a crowd, hold onto your chosen bag in front of you. So a cross body type bag or a bum bag are more favourites. It's debatable whether you should spread items across you, so cash in one place, phone in another, or have it all together. I like to have most stuff in one place that I can always pay attention to and have on my person. But I will have a card in a secret place as a fail safe. You can also leave stuff in a safe if there's one at your accommodation, but thefts from hotels do happen. I trust myself and my attention more than anything else, and definately more than any brand or item recommended. I thinBank cards, get modern internet bank account cards so you can instantly cancel if lost or stolen. Lots of old school banks are very poor for this kinda thing. I have a chase, Revolut and Monzo, and Tide for my business. All cancellable within a minute or less on my phone. sure the phone could be stolen too - haha. Italy isn't likely to be any more crime ridden than your own country. be wary but realistic.

I got a leash for my phone so I could carry it around my neck. That prevented me from getting in and out of my purse.
I also took a pic of my passport and had a photocopy in my purse, then left the real one in my room.

Ciao!

We are finishing our 6 week Italian adventure tomorrow 😢 (thankfully we have a few weeks left in other countries!). We are a family of 6 (our kids are 15, 12, 10 & 6) travelling from Australia.

Our Italian itinerary was:

Milan - only stayed 2 nights, primarily for my husband & sons to attend a football match at San Siro. They had an absolute ball!

Train to Venice.

Venice - stayed in a very cool & quirky Airbnb for 3 nights. Loved Venice, just walking around & getting lost. Took a tour boat to Murano & Burano one day which was interesting, especially the glass blowing demo. I probably couldn’t have stayed longer with the kids… anywhere they tried to kick a ball they got told off & so it was enough time with them (could absolutely go back without them sometime & enjoy some nicer restaurants etc 🤣).

Train to Bologna.

Bologna - loved it! Food was amazing, definitely the best we had in Italy. Gelato is amazing here! We got tickets on the day to walk up the tower, I was scared (I’m terrified of heights!), but all the kids were fine. View from the top is pretty great. I loved that they closed the main streets around the Piazza over the weekend to cars, it had a nice ‘festival’ vibe. Our Airbnb here was also great. Spent a morning at Giardini Margherita, where the kids got to kick the ball freely & enjoyed a game with some local children! We had 4 nights here & felt that was a good amount of time. We did a day trip to Modena & checked out the markets/bought parmigiano/tasted balsamic vinegar, which made for a fun day.

Train to Levanto.

Levanto - we stayed in a beautiful farmhouse through Airbnb that I cannot recommend highly enough (except the stairs to get back up… if you have a car, this wouldn’t be an issue!). We stayed here to explore 5 Terre because we met up with friends & needed a big house, which I couldn’t find in any of the 5 CT towns. Levanto was beautiful though & we spent half a day on a small boat looking at the CT towns from the water & it was a highlight of our entire trip. We also caught the train to the towns & hiked between Corniglia, Vernazza & Monterroso. Definitely more of a hike than a walk & it was a bit challenging at times keeping kids motivated, but we got there in the end & all loved it. We explored RioMaggiore & Manarola by train separately & loved Nessun Dorma for drinks/dinner!

Train to Florence via Pisa.

Pisa - we literally stored our bags near the station & walked to the leaning tower. It’s a bit of a trek, but totally worth it, we had a lot of fun trying to get the pictures right!

Florence - I could write a novel on all the ways I loved Florence! Someone here mentioned the Benheart store for leather & this was honestly one of the highlights of our trip. Ben was in the store & he (& his staff) are an absolute joy to be around! He had my kids in the street playing football while we browsed & honestly, the BEST shopping experience ever, I couldn’t walk into another leather shop after that, nothing could compare to our experience in there. We saw David & he is obviously incredible (I had pre-booked tickets for him & the Galleria Dell’Accademia) & we spent a lot of time just walking & looking at everything (we didn’t go into the Duomo, just admired it from outside). We were here 3 nights & could have happily stayed longer!

We then hired a car from Europcar (in the city) & I have to say, it was the worst car hire experience we’ve had. They didn’t have the car we’d booked months prior, then tried to blame it on us being there late (we had been there on time & had to stand in the queue for ages). It just went on & on, they were so rude, it was horrid. Anyway! We got a smaller car than we needed, so it was a squish, but we got everyone in & headed to Tuscany.

(Note… we had so many dramas trying to get a cab to take us from our accom to the car hire, they kept declining us & Uber doesn’t exist in Florence… so keep this in mind! If I’d known I would have organised a transfer car. We got a cab easily from the train station to our accom, there’s a big line for them there).

Tuscany - we had a week at Agriturismo Diacceroni & it was great. I wouldn’t have stayed there without kids, it was a little bit “summer camp”, but with kids it was perfect. We lazed by the pool, the kids did some horse riding, we did a pizza & pasta making course & a truffle hunt. The on-site restaurant was great & the apartment was really big. Would definitely recommend if you’re traveling with children! We did drive around to a few of the towns nearby & really loved them all. We did a winery tour at Fattoria Il Piano near San Gimignano & it was excellent.

From there we returned the car to Florence & got the train to Naples.

Naples - because we were only there for 2 nights (primarily to see Pompeii), I booked an Airbnb near the train station. The actual apartment was fantastic, but the area was a bit so-so. We never felt unsafe, it was just FULL of rubbish! We stepped over a rat amongst it all one day. We caught the train to Pompeii & had a tour with a guide I found on Airbnb experiences. She was brilliant, I would highly recommend her, especially for kids. That afternoon I booked a Spanish Quarter tour through GetYourGuide which I really enjoyed, but it was probably too much in one day for the kids, they were exhausted! They did love the Maradona stuff though! We had dinner at Trattoria Nennella (got there 20min before it opened & lined up), which was lots of fun - they turn the music on & the waiters all dance & sing, the kids LOVED this!

Flew Ryanair to Cagliari.

Sardinia - wow, this place is beautiful! We picked up a car at Cagliari airport & drove to our Airbnb in Costa Rei. It was a drive to the beach, but it didn’t matter because we wanted to explore a few anyway. We visited a few of the beaches up & down the coast & they were all magnificent! We organised a last minute snorkelling tour for half a day through a dive centre in Villasimius & this turned out to be a great idea! We did 2 fairly long snorkels in beautiful clear blue water, everyone really enjoyed this. The company was Archeo Diving & they were really excellent. Villasimius was a cool town, we really liked hanging out there. We had 4 nights, but could have spent a lot more, it is paradise!

Flew ITA Airways to Rome.

Rome - it was HOT!!! Really, really hot, almost unbearable. Thankfully our Airbnb had aircon. We stayed in Monti right behind the Roman Forum & it was a great apartment & spot. We did a Colosseum tour through LivTours, initially we had booked the underground tour, but we were victims of the cancellations, so it got changed. The Roman Forum part of the tour was interesting for me, but for the kids in the heat (& so soon after Pompeii, perhaps), it was just a long, hot day! Once we got into the Colosseum everyone really loved it, but 3 hours was a long time. We also did an early morning Vatican Museum/Sistine Chapel tour with LivTours, which started at 7:30 (although we did still have to queue until it opened at 8am). This was also really interesting for me… but probably went largely over the kids’ heads. Personally, I thought the 2 LivTours we did were really great, but in hindsight I may have looked harder for a tour guide that could tailor things more to the children, they were quite ‘serious’ information/content-heavy. Our guide in Pompeii navigated offering interesting info to us, while also engaging the kids so well, it was always going to be hard for anyone else to stack up!

We walked around Trastevere one afternoon & felt a bit like we were missing something… we didn’t really find any cool shops or anything interesting like I’d read. Maybe we were in the wrong place?! My daughter did get her ears pierced here though & I was really impressed with the shop that we had it done at. We found exactly what we thought we’d find in Trastevere, in Monti (right near where we stayed) though! Lots of cool arty shops, another lovely guy making beautiful leather pieces & good restaurants/bars. We actually stumbled across a brilliant burger bar here (T&C), right when everyone was feeling a bit over pasta & pizza!

Otherwise we walked ALOT around Rome! We went to the Pantheon the day after they introduced the new ticketing system & I had bought us each a ticket for €6 online. There was such confusion though with the new system that no one knew what was going on & tension between customers & staff got a bit high at times. They had various queues & people who hadn’t pre-booked tickets were walking right in while we had to stand & wait, it was chaos. I hope they’ve ironed out those kinks by now!

Another great thing we did in Rome was an early morning running tour (through Airbnb experiences). We met the guide at 6:30am & did about 10km past all the main points of interest - even though we’d already seen them, it was so cool to see the Colosseum without anyone around it & likewise for the other places. If you like running, I would highly recommend this, it was a great way to see the city & the guides were excellent!

We had 5 nights in Rome & it was probably 1 or 2 nights too many - perhaps because it was so hot, or perhaps having the kids & not being able to hop between restaurants like I would without them, we just kind of felt like there wasn’t a lot else we could do after we’d seen all the ‘hot spots’. It was probably the heat making us all grumpy 🤣.

Train to Venice Mestre.

Mestre - yes, we backtracked. Only because we booked our sons into the AC Milan Junior Football Camp in Cortina after I’d booked everything else! So we had a night at the Anda Venice Hostel near Mestre station & it was actually awesome (had another night a week later on our way back). Of course, the kids think it was the best accommodation ever!!! We hired a car from Alamo at the train station (easiest car hire ever, can recommend!).

Cortina D’Ampezzo - WOW! This place is amazing, we LOVED it! I can’t put into words how beautiful the Dolomites are, they really took my breath away every day. We stayed in the Hotel Alaska (the kids stayed here with the camp & we thought it best to stay close this time) & it was fantastic. The town of Cortina has lots of shops & great restaurants/bars. We drove around a bit to other towns/lakes & they were all gorgeous. We hired e-bikes one day & rode for half a day, lots of fun & great scenery! We caught the gondola up to a wine bar (Masi Wine Bar) which was fab - great wine & those views are perfection!!! We can’t wait to come back, it is a really magical spot!

We drove back to Mestre to fly out of Venice airport for Greece.

I booked all our train tickets through ItaliaRail & it was super easy. The train between Levanto & Florence wasn’t available to book until a couple of weeks prior, that was a little stressful, but we got there in the end! I booked business class seats where possible - it was nice to have assigned seats & a bit of space. There was always room for our bags above the seats or between seats.

We took backpacks with zip-off daypacks rather than suitcases. This has worked well for us as we haven’t had to wheel cases on cobblestones etc. & getting on/off trains has been totally fine. We have had to buy one extra bag so far though… the shopping here is great!!!

We used Stasher & Bounce to store bags - just check the reviews on the places you’re using & it should be fine. For us it worked really well. My preference though, is for stowyourbags.com We used them numerous times & it is just so easy. If there is one near where you’re going, I’d really recommend. Just book online & then use the code once you get there, such a great system.

We have loved exploring Italy, it’s been a great place to bring the kids. We’ve felt safe the entire time & met some really beautiful people along the way!

I will happily answer any questions, but we are still traveling for another month, so if I’m slow to reply, please forgive me!

As long as you plan ahead, and book the most important activities that you want to see ahead of time, you can absolutely do this on your own! Easy to get around in Italy, most people speak English, most of the signs are in both English and Italian, and in planning it yourself, you have complete control over where you stay (say, center of town rather than on the outskirts, if you prefer), how long you could stay at each venue (if you want to spend half a day at the Uffizi rather than an hour with the tour company's guide), and you can change things up easily. Have seen posts with women asking for packing tips but not noticed any from men. At home it gets up to 32 degrees Celsius (90 Fahrenheit) and we go to
Maui every second year. I will say for some reason I have never sweated as much as I did in Rome or
Pompeii and this next week is going to be even warmer even on the coast.

At home I typically wear black and grey shirts year round so for this trip is thought I would wear some colours. Brought several lighter coloured t-shirts and button up shirts. I know we are all human but looking like my sweat glands are malfunctioning particularly in photos isn’t a look I would chose if I can avoid it.

So here are two photos just as examples for anyone else who is planning on coming here in the summer.

The check shirt is way better option than the solid lighter blue one.

The striped shirt despite being a darker blue is a way better option than the lavender one.

Literally planning on trying to find somewhere to donate 12 shirts to free up space in my bag as I have not and will not be wearing them over the next week.

As an aside the button up style is also much cooler to wear than a t-shirt.

comments.comment_text: There is a ph balanced soap that helps for sweating and it makes all the difference in the world along with how much water u are in taking so look that up too. I've heard how horribly hot it is in Italy. I'd still go lighter cotton on the shirts that u have out.

Paying attention to fabric content is also of help. Cotton will breathe better than polyester. Modal and tencel both have moisture wicking properties as well. Linen also is lighter than cotton, is also natural and breathes well.
Linen button ups are the best and coolest shirts. My husband lives in those and v-necked white cotton t-shirts all summer.

Totally agree.

I had a couple button ups and a few breathable synthetic golf (polo) shirts that did me well.

I also packed some Hanes mesh undershirts. Synthetic moisture wicking base layers are life savers.

Precisely why I wear nothing but performance material polos and shirts in mid to dark colours when I'm in Europe in summer. I may be sweating but you won't see it and the perf material wicks it away very well. Perf golf wear for daily excursions has been the key for me for years of summer travel in europe.
